item.title: New York Times Strands Hints and Answers for October 26, 2024
item.description:
Strands has a new puzzle grid filled with seven themed words, but you only get one clue to help you guess them all. In order to complete this puzzle, you might be in search of a helping hand that isn't the in-game hint system.

In this article, you can find all sorts of hints for today's Strands . There are things like general overall clues to the themed, individual word spoilers with screenshots, an explanation of the puzzle and clue, and even the full answer to this mobile puzzle game.

The NYT Games Strands Puzzle #237 October 26, 2024

The Strands puzzle for today has the clue Sing-Song . There are seven items to find: one Spangram category and six themed words.

New York Times Games Strands Clues

Each of the three expandable sections below each contains one spoiler-free clue that will help you get closer to the answer. Unlike the in-game hints, none of the theme words will appear in any of them.

General Hint 1

General Hint 2

General Hint 3

Spoilers for Two of the Words in Today's Strands

The two sections below each contain just one spoiled word from today's puzzle. Open them up to see what each word is and where it belongs in the letter grid of this challenging puzzle game.

Spoiler 1

Spoiler 2

The Answer to Today's New York Times Games Strands

If you would like to see the answer to the New York Times Games Strands for October 26, 2024, check out the expandable section below. It contains the Spangram and all the themed words, and there is also a screenshot of a finished puzzle to see where all those words fit into the puzzle grid.

Today's Strands Explained

In the section below is an explanation for this PC puzzle game. Open it up to peek at how the clue, the themed words, and the Spangram all work together in perfect harmony.

Want to play? Check out the New York Times Games Strands website available on almost any device with a browser.

item.title: Dead By Daylight: Best Builds For The Good Guy (Chucky)
item.description:
With a flair for the dramatic and a wit as deadly as his knives, Chucky – the serial killer doll from the comedy horror franchise Child’s Play – arrives in Dead by Daylight with ferocious speed and unnerving stealth. Capable of hiding himself from Survivors with his Hidey-Ho ability, Chucky can launch ferocious stealth attacks, rushing forward with his Slice & Dice to quickly close gaps and inflict damage.

To fully make the most of Chucky’s powers in Dead by Daylight , players must adapt quickly to Survivors and play around loops carefully. These select perks and add-ons can vastly improve Killers’ chances of success, featuring builds with both teachable and non-teachable perks for players with a variety of access to other DLC Killers.

Updated October 25, 2024 by Lewis Smyth: Chucky has received some significant changes since the deadly doll first arrived in Dead by Daylight nearly a year ago, though he remains a top-tier Killer. This updated guide features tweaked builds and a new best add-on tier list.

The Good Guy: Best Beginner Build (2024)

For players who only have access to Chucky’s perks, this impactful build makes use of two Good Guy perks. This build focuses on tracking Survivors and Exposing them throughout the game with Bitter Murmur and Friends ‘till the End. Meanwhile, Batteries Included and Hex: No One Escapes Death work in tandem to increase The Killer’s speed in the endgame and leave all Survivors vulnerable to an instant down.

  • Batteries Included (The Good Guy) – Gain a 5% Haste bonus when within 12 meters of a completed generator and for five seconds after leaving it.
  • Friends ‘till the End (The Good Guy) – After hooking a Survivor that is not the Obsession, the Obsession becomes Exposed for 20 seconds and reveals their aura for 10 seconds. After hooking the Obsession, another random Survivor screams, revealing their position, and becomes the Obsession.
  • Hex: No One Escapes Death (General Perk) – After the final generator is completed, all Survivors suffer from the Exposed status ailment and you gain a 4% Haste effect until the Hex Totem is cleansed.
  • Bitter Murmur (General Perk) – Each time a generator is completed, the auras of Survivors within 16 meters of that generator are revealed for 5 seconds. Once the last generator is complete, all Survivors’ auras are revealed for 10 seconds.

The Good Guy: Best Build (2024)

A short, slow-moving Killer like Chucky often needs information on what is directly around him. To this end, arguably the best build to run on The Good Guy in Dead by Daylight includes Scourge Hook: Pain Resonance and Pop Goes the Weasel to decimate generator progress and force Survivors from them. Furthermore, the impressive strength of Corrupt Intervention stalls generators and draws Survivors near in the early game while Nowhere to Hide allows him to find those hiding nearby.

  • Corrupt Intervention (The Plague) – At the start of the trial, the 3 generators furthest from the killer's starting location are blocked for 120 seconds or until the first survivor is downed.
  • Scourge Hook: Pain Resonance (The Artist) – The Killer starts with four tokens. For each different Survivor hooked on a white Scourge Hook, lose one token and explode the generator with the most progress, causing it to lose 25% of progress.
  • Nowhere to Hide (The Knight) – Kicking a generator will reveal the aura of all Survivors within 24 meters for 5 seconds.
  • Pop Goes the Weasel (The Clown) – For 45 seconds after hooking a Survivor, damaging a generator will remove 20% of its current progress.

The Good Guy: Best Add-Ons Tier List

Tier

Add-On Name

Add-On Description

Add-On Comments

S

Rat Poison

Auras of Survivors are revealed for 5 seconds while performing a Slice & Dice

Allows you to out-mindgame Survivors at most loops by reading their movements constantly

Power Drill

A successful Slice & Dice reduces Hidey-Ho Mode cooldown by 10%

Reduced power cooldown gives you the opportunity to land quicker follow-up attacks

A

Jump Rope

Increases Slice & Dice duration by 8%

Gives you 8% extra range on Slice & Dice attacks, helping you hit distant Survivors

Automatic Screwdriver

Missed Slice & Dice attacks reduces Hidey-Ho Mode cooldown by 8%

Like the Power Drill, getting back into Hidey-Ho Mode a little sooner can make a big difference

Electric Carving Knife

Decreases Slice & Dice miss cooldown by 5%

Good for beginners, this add-on makes missing your attacks more forgiving, like The Demogorgon's Mew's Guts add-on

Portable TV

Increases Slice & Dice duration by 70% once the exit gates are powered

An exceptional endgame add-on that allows you to cover huge distances in Slice & Dice once all generators are complete

Yardstick

Scampers reveal nearby Survivor auras for 3 seconds

Similar to the Rat Poison, the Yardstick lets you track Survivors as you Slice & Dice, better enabling you to land special attacks

B

Straight Razor

Slice & Dice attacks inflict Mangled and Hemorrhage for 80 seconds

Like Sloppy Butcher, this add-on can slow down healing and enable health state pressure

Hair Spray & Candle

Basic attacks remove 20% Hidey-Ho Mode charge

Can better enable double-tapping Survivors by allowing you more time to land a basic attack followed by a Slice & Dice

Iridescent Amulet

Increases Hidey-Ho duration by 50%. Basic attacks immediately end Hidey-Ho Mode

Gives you more purchase to sneak up on Survivors in Hidey-Ho Mode from a greater distance before you have to reveal yourself. This also helps in mindgaming Survivors at loops as you hide your Red Stain longer

Strobing Light

Decreases your Terror Radius by 8 meters while Hidey-Ho is in cooldown

Works well in tandem with perks like The Doctor's Monitor and Abuse to get the jump on Survivors

C

Hard Hat

Performing a Scamper under a pallet immediately breaks it

Can be helpful in chase by saving time breaking pallets, though Scampering under pallets isn't always the best play

Good Guy Box

Decreases Slice & Dice hit cooldown by 7%

An okay effect, but barely noticeable

Running Shoes

Gain 2% movement speed for 5 seconds after a Scamper

Similar to The Xenomorph's haste add-on, the Running Shoes provide a very mild effect

Pile of Nails

Manually ending Hidey-Ho Mode will retain your Undetectable effect for 3 seconds

Not bad, and can catch Survivors off-guard, but manually ending Hidey-Ho Mode is something you'll rarely want to do

D

Plastic Bag

Survivors become Exhausted for 15 seconds after walking through an illusory Footfall

Difficult to ascertain the value of, as the effect is very inconsistent

Tiny Scalpel

Blood pools are more visible in Hidey-Ho Mode

A perfectly fine tracking effect, but not incredibly valuable

Doll Eyes

Nearby windows and downed pallets are revealed while in Hidey-Ho Mode

Not particularly useful in a typical game unless you're unfamiliar with typical map and tile layouts

F

Silk Pillow

Decreases your Terror Radius by 8 meters, but increases Slice & Dice charge time by 50%

Unless you are actively pursuing a small Terror Radius build on Chucky, the Silk Pillow's costly downside is rarely worth the tradeoff

Mirror Shards

You can see illusory Footfalls around Survivors

As you can also hear nearby illusory Footfalls, this add-on can actually make tracking Survivors through walls harder in Hidey-Ho Mode

item.title: How Dragon Age: The Veilguard's Marketing Could Give Mass Effect 4 Lots to Chew on
item.description:
Dragon Age: The Veilguard and Mass Effect 4 are likely going to be two of the most important RPGs of the modern era, whether they are good, bad, or something in the middle. This is not only because Dragon Age and Mass Effect are among the best RPG franchises of all time, but also because of what they represent for BioWare as a company. The world will be watching these games to see if the once-revered studio has truly got its "magic back."

If early impressions and gameplay footage of Dragon Age: The Veilguard are any indication, though, it would appear that BioWare very well may have gotten this magic touch back after stumbling with releases like Anthem and Mass Effect: Andromeda . Informative, sober info dumps featuring real gameplay footage and in-engine cutscenes have opened a portal between Veilguard and prospective buyers, as the ostensible strengths and weaknesses of the game are on full display. This is in contrast to some other AAA games, whose marketing can tend to feel highly curated and cinematic, to the point where it obscures the actual game that players will ultimately engage with. But a transparent approach to marketing is generally a good omen for a game, showing that it has nothing to hide, and hopefully BioWare continues this trend for future releases.

Mass Effect 4's Marketing Should Follow In Dragon Age: The Veilguard's Footsteps

Transparency Will Be Key for Mass Effect 4

There are many reasons why people don't like Mass Effect: Andromeda , not the least of which being its fundamental departures from its predecessors and rough state at launch. It's rather unfortunate because, though Andromeda isn't all bad, it left a bad taste in the mouths of audiences as the last Mass Effect release. If BioWare had only dropped the ball with Anthem , it would be easy to argue that it simply wasn't the right developer for a co-op looter shooter. But Mass Effect is its flagship franchise, making Andromeda 's quality indicative of the company's overall decline in the eyes of many.

In other words, BioWare has a lot to prove with Mass Effect 4 . The Mass Effect series is suffering an identity crisis that isn't shared by Dragon Age , which players last experienced through the well-received Dragon Age: Inquisition . Plus, the story of Dragon Age is easier to continue than Mass Effect 's, which is definitively concluded after Mass Effect 3 . This isn't a death sentence, by any means—franchises backed into such corners have made great comebacks before—but audiences will definitely be wary of Mass Effect 4 , even as BioWare starts to roll out more substantial trailers.

What BioWare Needs to Show With Mass Effect 4

Dragon Age: The Veilguard 's previews have been revelatory, giving invaluable insight into not only the game's story, but its mechanics and world systems as well. Combat, dialog trees, and level design have all been touted in these previews, which helps audiences form a firm yet tentative image of what the final product will be like. Mass Effect 4 needs to do the same thing.

Showing the story will be important, certainly, but prospective buyers also need to get a clear and comprehensive picture of what the gameplay will look like; cinematics should only make up a minority of Mass Effect 4 's promotional material, especially if they aren't representative of what will actually be in the game. Long, mostly uncut looks at Mass Effect 4 's gameplay, similar to what BioWare has done so far for Veilguard , seem like the best call, serving as both a sign of confidence and a gesture of goodwill to consumers who need a clear picture of Mass Effect's next chapter. It's been over a decade since players have seen BioWare's grand vision of the Milky Way, so such clarity is essential.

item.title: How to get Radiant Shards in No Man's Sky
item.description:
In No Man's Sky , Radiant Shards are a precious resource players can get only on certain planets, and finding them can be tricky. To complete The Cursed Expedition, space explorers need to get plenty of these precious materials.

So, we've come up with a simple guide on how to farm Radiant Shards with ease. Get your Multitools ready, because you will be diving into some of the most hostile worlds the galaxy has ever seen, and battling against the forces of the Corrupted Sentinels to get some loot.

Where To Find Radiant Shards In No Man's Sky

To find Radiant Shards in No Man's Sky, players need to travel to dissonant planets, which are Aggressive Sentinel Activity planets that were also affected by The Corruption. These worlds are characterized by their harsh weather and purplish color. Most importantly, they're filled to the brim with corrupted life forms that will attack the player on sight.

To mine Radiant Shards, players need to have at least the A-Grade Mod Advanced Mining Laser equipped on their Multitools. Remember that mods of the same type need to be grouped together to be considered active.

Finding a Radiant Shard cumulus will not be easy. They can be spotted from afar thanks to their pinkish glowing light, and the energy that surrounds them. Like Storm Crystals, these formations are more frequently found on planets with harsh weather, but the Sentinels on said planet need to be affected by the Corruption.

To extract Radiant Shards, players will have to dig until they break the formations with their lasers . Doing so will alert every nearby Sentinel or Corrupted Life Force, which will then make a message pop up on the screen: "The Swarm Is Searching." This means the corrupted Sentinel forces are sending scouts to the area where the players extracted the Radiant Shards.

Players can fight these enemies off to earn Atlantideum and other important resources. Alternatively, they can simply dodge them by running and relocating, or using their Cloaking Devices. Keep in mind that every crystal formation will only yield 1 Radiant Shard , just like other precious resources like Gravitino Balls (which also happens to alert Sentinels when players extract it).

How To Use Radiant Shards In No Man's Sky

Radiant Shards can be used to craft the following recipes in No Man's Sky:

  • Resonance Amplifier: crafted using Di-hydrogen x160, Gravitino Ball x3, and Radiant Shard x1 in the Advanced Refinery.
  • Scan Harmoniser: crafted using Radiant Shard x1, Microprocessor x1, and Runaway Mould x100 in the Advanced Refinery.
  • Nanite Cumulus: crafted by refining Radiant Shards (each Radiant Shard is equal to 50 Nanites).

Getting lots of Radiant Shards can be useful for farming Nanites, as each Shard can be refined into 50 Nanites. This will be helpful for players trying to complete the Milestone titled Reality Foam, which can be found in Phase 5 of The Cursed Expedition.

item.title: Yakuza Kiwami: Best Accessories
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Yakuza Kiwami revamped an outdated classic, offering a modernized experience for fans.
  • New items like the Locker Key Watcher make gameplay more intuitive and enjoyable.
  • Accessories like the Hercules Gloves enhance combat mechanics, making it easier to control and punish enemies.

Yakuza Kiwami lets players jump into an adventure in the series that was in dire need of an overhaul. While the original game has its charms, there's no denying that the dated gameplay and a lack of familiar Yakuza elements meant that RGG Studio would always be in the right if they decided to give this game the remake treatment it deserved.

With a suite of new items, features, and gameplay elements that do a great job of modernizing the experience, it's easy to see why Yakuza Kiwami should be held in high regard as one of the best games in the series and a perfect entry point for fans who want to follow the series' plotline based on their release dates as opposed to plot chronology. As players explore Kamurocho, they'll get their hands on some valuable items that do a great job of helping players customize Kiryu in their image.

1 Locker Key Watcher

Let's Players Know When They're Near A Locker Key

  • Cost: 3 CP
  • Where to Find: Shrine

The lockers in Kamurocho house a bunch of impressive equipment and items, compelling players to keep an eye out on anything that's twinkling in the city. However, there are only so many locker keys players can find using their senses before they need something to nudge them in the right direction.

The Locker Key Watcher is a perfect accessory for players who don't want the act of locker key hunting to become too much of a headache. If players are in the general vicinity of a key, then this accessory starts pinging. It's a simple and great way for players to avoid the hassle of having to pick out every locker key without a sixth sense of sorts.

2 Card Watcher

Let's Players Know When They're Near A MesuKing Card

  • Cost: 5 CP
  • Where to Find: Shrine

The female wrestling matches that players could gamble on in Yakuza 0 were a fun distraction, but they didn't feel all that fleshed out. This changed in Yakuza Kiwami by using the framework of this auto-battling system and integrating it with a card collection minigame to make for a delightful combination.

MesuKing is a great side activity for players to be invested in, especially if they find some powerful cards scattered around in Kamurocho. The Card Watcher accessory makes this hunt easier, and players will sport a deck of strong fighters in no time with this item equipped.

3 Collateral Damage Belt

Enemies Also Fall If They Knock Kiryu Down

  • Cost: N/A
  • Where to Find: Gambling Hall

There's nothing more frustrating than watching Kiryu fall after an enemy lands a lucky combo or a large foe imposes his presence. However, these enemies can be punished with an accessory that makes them topple over too for daring to humiliate the Dragon of Dojima.

It's funny to see enemies flail helplessly on the ground after landing a major blow on Kiryu, preventing them from taking advantage of the player's vulnerability. It may be a pain to go through the Gambling Hall to gain the Collateral Damage Belt, but it's well worth the effort once Kiryu can make the most of its special effect in combat.

4 Stone Of Enduring

Kiryu Survives A Fatal Blow With 1 Health Remaining

  • Cost: 30,000 Coliseum Points
  • Where to Find: Substory #47 (Crisis on the Crapper), Locker G5, and the Coliseum Shop

With the sheer amount of restoratives at a player's behest, it's easy to see why one wouldn't care about an accessory that saves them from the brink of death. However, it's always possible for players to not pay attention to Kiryu's health bar in combat, making for an embarrassing occasion when the Dragon falls in combat to some unworthy mooks.

This can be avoided with the Stone of Enduring, an accessory that breaks after Kiryu's health is depleted and lets him survive with 1 HP. It's a warning call to the protagonist that gives them one final chance to heal up before dying a humiliating death.

5 Goddess Of Children Amulet

Enemies Don't Rush Kiryu

  • Cost: 1,000 CP
  • Where to Find: Substory #42 (The Cell Phone Plan) and the Coliseum Shop

Most people may assume that Yakuza Kiwami is as easy as they come, but these people will be singing a different tune after being mobbed by a truckload of enemies. It becomes incredibly frustrating to try and get a hit in when enemies are constantly landing cheap shots and combos on Kiryu.

Players who don't want to succumb to the numbers game can use a simple accessory that does a great job of quelling an enemy's rage. Now, Kiryu has all the time in the world to try out new combos and build up enough Heat to take out multiple enemies in one fell swoop.

6 Hercules Gloves

Enemies Find It Harder To Escape A Grab

  • Cost: N/A
  • Where to Find: Gambling Hall

Grabs are integral to Yakuza 's combat, letting players engage in effective crowd control and unleash powerful Heat Actions from this position. This makes it important to find ways to prolong these grabs so that enemies can be dragged into position and punished.

The Hercules Gloves can be found after grinding in the Gambling Hall, allowing players to make it easier to grab enemies and manipulate them as players see fit. Given how powerful grabs are in this game, it's easy to see why Kiryu would benefit a ton from this accessory.

7 Sacrifice Stone

Kiryu Survives A Fatal Blow And Restores Full Health

  • Cost: N/A
  • Where to Find: Substory #24 (Prodigal Son) and Locker B1

One of the rarest and most valuable accessories in the game, players who want an edge against a particularly tough opponent should come equipped with the Sacrifice Stone. It's an item that one should use sparingly, given that it breaks after use.

If players drop to zero health, then this accessory will restore Kiryu in combat at once with full vitality. It's an incredible item that allows players to weather the storm of particularly tough bosses and catch them off-guard with an impressive Second Wind.

8 War God Talisman

Passive Heat Regeneration

  • Cost: N/A
  • Where to Find: Complete all Ultimate Battles from the Climax Battles section

The best accessory in Yakuza Kiwami is the one that lets players enjoy a huge benefit in combat. Such is the case with the War God Talisman, which allows players to generate Heat in combat without having to remain active and expose themselves to enemy attacks.

This means that players are never going to experience a situation where their Heat is depleting after being too passive in combat. However, acquiring this accessory is easier said than done, since players have to endure some tough fights in the Climax Battles section before unlocking this item.
